subject: TestCase classes and code
msgSnippet: I suspect I m not properly understanding what is meant by TestCase. You ve got a definition that more than simply - extends JUnit.TestCase. Could you define
messageBody:
I suspect I'm not properly understanding what is meant by TestCase.
You've got a definition that more than simply - extends JUnit.TestCase.
Could you define TestCase and comment on our testing system.

What we have a one to one correspondence of test classes to production
classes. For example, a CalculatorEngine.java and
CalculatorEngineTest.java (extended from TestCase) in parallel
directories so that they're in the same package. When we we've written a
few tests and find that some setup code is repeated in more than one test
class (often because it's setting up a mock database or file system) that
goes into something we call a XxxxTestUtility class - maybe
OracleTestUtility.java.

I'm wondering if our TestUtility is what you're calling a fixture even
tho it doesn't extend TestCase. This class will setup the sometimes
complicated objects, often instantiating several objects and setting
their state. It's methods are then called by the test classes that extend
TestCase and are called in test suites.

We still have a one-to-one correspondence of test classes to production
classes which seems to help make sure that we test everything. And tells
us where to look for code that tests a given class. If it matters, this
project was started a few years before we'd heard of unit tests and long
before test driven development reached us.

On Sat, 14 Dec 2002 16:55:56 -0500 "J. B. Rainsberger"
<jbr@...> writes:
> So said Steven Taschuk on 2002-12-14 --------------------
>
> >Quoth Dave Astels <dave@...>:
> >> TestCases and Classes being tested should have only coincedental
> >> correspondance. A TestCase is the embodiment of a *fixture*...
> a
> >> specific context in which tests are run. As such it should
> contain
> >> only those tests (i.e. test methods) which run in the context of
> the
> >> fixture that the TestCase embodies.
> > [...]
> >
> >I entirely agree that TestCases are (despite the name) intended to
> >represent fixtures, and that mindlessly creating one TestCase per
> >class under test is a Bad Thing. Your example in a subsequent
> >post of separate TestCases for a list implementation illustrates
> >the point quite nicely.
> >
> >However, I think there are cases in which it is sensible to have
> >one TestCase for one class. For example, suppose we have a
> >Comparator which sorts Integers lexicographically according to
> >their written-out forms in English. The class has no internal
> >state; all instances are equivalent.
>
> Certainly: if there is no commonality of setup, then there may be
> no
> motivation whatever to separate test methods into many test cases.
>
> >We might take the view that, when a TestCase is closely tied to a
> >single class this way, the fixture under test consists simply of
> >the class itself (rather than an instance with some specific
> >state). If there is nothing else in common among the test
> >methods, it is not unreasonable to leave them all in the same
> >TestCase, rather than, say, putting each in its own TestCase.
>
> I can find no argument against this.
